text: "Ja, vi elsker dette landet" (, meaning "Yes, we love this country") is the national anthem of Norway. Before it became the country's anthem, it was a patriotic song written in 1859 by a Norwegian writer named BjÃ¸rnstjerne BjÃ¸rnson. His cousin Rikard Nordraak set his lyrics to music in 1863. Until 2017, it had been an unofficial anthem of Norway, alongside "SÃ¸nner av Norge" and "Norges Skaal".https://www.stortinget.no/no/Saker-og- publikasjoner/Publikasjoner/Referater/Stortinget/2019-2020/refs-201920-12-11?m=3 Stortinget - MÃ¸te onsdag den 11. desember 2019 - Sak nr. 3. Stortinget. 2019-12-11. Â«Innstilling fra familie- og kulturkomiteen om Representantforslag fra stortingsrepresentantene Morten Wold, Hans Andreas Limi, Per-Willy Amundsen, Solveig Horne, Morten Stordalen, BÃ¥rd Hoksrud og Erlend Wiborg om Ã¥ vedta at Â«Ja, vi elsker dette landetÂ» skal anerkjennes av Stortinget som Norges offisielle nasjonalsang (Innst. 47 S (2019â€“2020), jf. Dokument 8:161 S (2018â€“2019))Â» ==Lyrics== This song has eight verses in total. However, only the first, seventh and eighth verses (highlighted in bold) are used for the national anthem. === Norwegian original === Words of the song in Norwegian Words of the song when it was first printed Pronunciation of these words using the IPA Meaning of the song in Simple English Ja, vi elsker dette landet, som det stiger frem, furet, vÃ¦rbitt over vannet, med de tusen hjem, â€” elsker, elsker det og tenker pÃ¥ vÃ¥r far og mor ğ„† og den saganatt som senker drÃ¸mme pÃ¥ vÃ¥r jord. ğ„‡ Norske mann i hus og hytte, takk din store Gud! [mÅ“d.rÉ™.nÉ™ hÉ‘Ër É¡rÉ›tË] ğ„† [hÉ‘Ër dÉ›n ËˆhÃ¦.rÉ™ ËˆstÉªÌ‚l.lÉ™ ËˆlÉ›m.pÉ™t] [sÉ”Ë Ê‹iË Ê‹É‘nt Ê‹oËr rÉ›tË] ğ„‡ [jÉ‘Ë Ê‹iË ËˆÉ›Ì‚l.skÉ›Ì r ËˆdÉ›Ì‚t.tÉ™ ËˆlÉ‘Ì‚n.nÉ™] [sÉ”m deË ËˆstÃ®Ë.É¡É›Ì r frÉ›m] [ËˆfÊ‰Ì‚Ë.rÉ›t ËˆÊ‹Ã¦Ër.bÉªtË ËˆoË.Ê‹É›Ì r ËˆÊ‹É‘Ì‚n.nÉ™] [meË diË ËˆtÊ‰Ë.sÉ™n jÉ›m] [É” sÉ”m ËˆfeËd.rÉ›Ì s kÉ‘mp hÉ‘Ër ËˆheË.Ê‹É™t] [deË É‘ËÊ‹ nÅ“Ëd tÉªl sÃ¦ÉªÌ¯r] ğ„† [É”.sÉ”Ë Ê‹iË nor deË blÉªr ËˆkreË.Ê‹É™t] [fÉ”rË dÉ›ts freËd Ê‚loËr lÃ¦ÉªÌ¯r] ğ„‡ Yes, we love this country as it rises forth, hilly, worn by weather, over the water, with the thousands of homes, â€” love, love it and think of our father and mother ğ„† and the night of the saga that lays dreams upon our earth. ğ„‡ This country Harald united with his army of heroes, this country HÃ¥kon protected while Ã˜yvind sung; upon the country that Olav painted with his blood the cross, ğ„† from its heights Sverre spoke against Rome. ğ„‡ Farmers made their axes sharper wherever an army came forward, Tordenskjold moved roughly along the coast so that we could see it back home. Even women stood up and fought as if they were men; ğ„† others could only cry but that soon would end! ğ„‡ Sure, we were not many but we were enough, when we were tested sometimes, and it was risky; we would rather burn our land than to be defeated; ğ„† just remember what happened down at Fredrikshald! ğ„‡ We have dealt with hard times, were at last no longer acknowledged; but in the worst pain, blue-eyed freedom was born to us. It gave us our father's strength to carry starvation and war, ğ„† it gave death itself its honour â€“ and it gave us peace. ğ„‡ The enemy threw away his weapon, a part of his helmet went up, we, in wonder, to him stepped up, because he was our brother. Driven to a stand by shame we went to the south; ğ„† now we three brothers stand united, and shall stand like that! ğ„‡ Norwegian man in house and cabin, thank your great God! He wanted to protect the country, although things looked dark. All the fights that our fathers have fought, and the mothers have cried, ğ„† the Lord has quietly eased so we won our rights. ğ„‡ Yes, we love this country as it rises forth, hilly, worn by weather, over the water, with the thousands of homes. And as the fathers' struggle has raised it from need to victory, ğ„† even we, when it's demanded, will make a camp for its peace. ğ„‡ ===English version=== An English recording of the song, based on the first, seventh and eighth stanzas, was popular among Norwegian Americans sometime in the 1900s. ==Controversies== ===Norwegian independence=== In 1905, the Union between Sweden and Norway was broken apart after many years of Norwegian struggle for equality between the two states. The declaration of independence by Norway made Sweden really angry, bringing both of them to the brink of war. In Sweden, pro-war conservatives were opposed by the Social Democrats, whose leaders Hjalmar Branting and Zeth HÃ¶glund spoke out for a peaceful settlement with Norway. Swedish socialists sang "Ja, vi elsker dette landet" to show their support for Norway leaving the Union. ===Nazi occupation=== During the Second World War, the anthem was used both by the Norwegian resistance and the Nazi collaborators. When the Nazis took control of Norway, they did not let anyone play this anthem. ===Urdu translation=== In May 2006, a newspaper proposed that the national anthem be translated into Urdu, since there are a lot of Pakistani immigrants in Norway.Vil ha Â«Ja vi elskerÂ» pÃ¥ urdu (11 May 2008). The editor's idea was that people from other ethnic groups should be able to honour their adopted country with devotion, even if they're not fluent in Norwegian. This was, however, met with criticism.Fr.p. sier nei til "Ja vi elsker" pÃ¥ urdu Someone even sent a bunch of hate mail to the editor, calling her a traitor and threatening her with decapitation.Oslo - Aftenposten ==References== Category:1860s songs Category:European anthems Category:National symbols of Norway
title: Ja, vi elsker dette landet
